Chapter 84

◎Combined Two Chapters◎

"Empress, the emperor has sent several boxes of autumn plums. They appear undamaged, so I brought them all over," Chief Steward Qin An announced from outside.

Huiyin opened the boxes and had a dish washed for tasting. The plums were a deep purple with a red tint, both sour and sweet—just the right flavor. After her menstruation passed, she felt revitalized, her skin had improved, and she was in an excellent mood, especially with the food specially sent by Li Cheng.

Seeing Ling Lu bring tea over, Huiyin quickly said, "I just ate plums and can't drink hot tea yet, or my stomach will hurt. You can take it and drink it yourself. Also, please keep this box of plums for me."

Ling Lu smiled and replied, "Yes, His Majesty is truly good to you, remembering how much you love plums. We didn't even know."

"I love eating these, but I love them too much, which is why my stomach hurts easily. Usually, I just don't have them delivered. I didn't expect the emperor to remember. I vaguely recall these are from Lingnan. It would be laborious and costly to continue doing this. I'll write a letter to him, asking him not to worry about me in the future." Huiyin shook her head.

Ling Lu said, "If it were any other monarch, I wouldn't dare to guarantee, but our emperor truly cares for his people and would never cause laborious and costly actions."

The plums were a small matter. As winter approached, the palace began preparing winter clothes. Huiyin instructed the wardrobe department to make clothes for the palace residents first, including the Empress Dowager, Princess Wei, Yin Cifei, Princess Jianjia, Prince Yuzhang, and others. Clothes were also made for Jing'er and Zhan'er, and even Guo Xing, who lived in the palace.

At the same time, Huiyin sent some warm clothing to the imperial mausoleum, saying, "They guard the mausoleum and can't leave. It's hard work."

Previously, Cui Yuehuan thought Huiyin wanted to let the people at the mausoleum fend for themselves. Unexpectedly, she sent cotton clothes and quilts, and Madame Ji remarked at home, "I must say, the Empress is indeed too kind."

Elder Madame Xu, sitting above, uncharacteristically agreed, "If you don't remove the roots, they'll just grow back when spring comes. Those people are descendants of the disgraced crown prince, causing misery. Given her young age, Madam should also advise her."

Referring to the Empress as "she" was something only Elder Madame Xu would dare to do.

Madame Ji, who used to endure silently, now felt the need to speak, "Madam Xu, please be careful with your words. The Empress is wise and compassionate, far beyond our ability to judge."

Elder Madame Xu almost blurted out that she was the elder but remembered that Huiyin was the Empress. Her face flushed with embarrassment. Sitting nearby, De Yin, aware that her grandmother was standing up for her, felt a mix of resentment towards the palace people, especially since Li Heng had drugged her.

Thus, she helped smooth things over, "Madam, this is the tea I brewed myself. Please try it."

Madame Ji graciously accepted the gesture, praising De Yin, "Your tea-brewing skills are excellent."

De Yin humbly replied, aware that her poor health required constant medical attention, which Madame Ji diligently arranged. She no longer harbored the same hostility towards others; at least Madame Ji didn't deliberately withhold anything from her. Living under someone else's roof, enduring some grievances was inevitable.

Madame Xin chimed in, "I remember the eldest young miss used to have a maid who was exceptionally skilled at brewing tea, capable of thirty-six tea arts."

That was Yunzhi, but she betrayed her. De Yin didn't want to mention her anymore.

Imperial Mausoleum

Yunzhi emptied the chamber pot early in the morning and hurried back to her room to dress her daughter and lift her clothes for her son to nurse. After finishing these tasks, she broke out in a sweat.

When she left the palace, she had some silver for rewards. Princess Wei forbade them to take anything, but money talks, and she used these funds to get extra food for her daughter and some rice paste. For herself, she was content with cornmeal porridge, a small dish of pickles, and a palm-sized bun.

However, winter was approaching, and the quilts were too thin, the jackets mere lined clothes, offering no warmth.

If her lady could send some, it would be wonderful. As the elder sister of Princess Wei, she should be treated kindly. Initially, she did betray her lady, but she never harmed her and even actively helped her during difficult times.

She was disappointed; instead, it was Princess Wei who sent the cotton clothes, delivered by her own brother.

When Huiyin asked Pei Shuo to deliver the clothes, she gave him a task: observe how the Wei family woman lived. If she treated these as treasures, it indicated she wasn't adapting and had no support. If she appeared indifferent, even disdainful, and had better items in her room, it suggested she had secret support.

Wei Liangdi, having borne the emperor's first son, was not someone Wei Duo would abandon entirely. It wasn't that Wei Duo loved and valued his daughter and grandson so much, but in his current situation, claiming the title of emperor meant facing greater opposition. Thus, under the guise of Li's descendants, Wei Liangdi's son was under strict surveillance.

Yunzhi was delighted to receive the quilts and even more so when she saw the cotton clothes. Though the fabric was indigo linen, which was relatively expensive, the cotton clothes were still very good. Holding her daughter's hand, she said joyfully, "This is wonderful. We can get through this winter comfortably."

Upon seeing this, Wei Liangdi, who was standing nearby, had a look of mockery in her eyes.

The distributor of the cotton clothes called out, "Wei, come and get yours."

Wei Liangdi, who was once the daughter of a chancellor like Wei Duo and the top figure under the Eastern Palace, was being treated this way. Furious, she grabbed the cotton clothes and mattress, and upon entering her room, threw them on the floor and stomped on them, saying, "One day, when my son becomes emperor, I'll make you all cry."

……

Pei Shuo couldn't help but admire his sister. Instead of immediately checking the people on the list, she took a different approach and sent him to investigate Wei Liangdi first. It turned out to be a fruitful decision.

He pretended to return with his team but doubled back to observe the surroundings.

As for Huiyin, after receiving the list, she couldn't fully trust it. As she had done this time, Huiyin asked them to verify two points: first, whether their backgrounds matched what they claimed, and second, whether their families had recently become wealthy.

However, these points could also be falsified, so she only used them as a reference and didn't fully trust them.

"The Empress Dowager has submitted a request to enter again," said Nanny Nan.

This Madam Ma was Xun Rou. After returning to the capital, Xun Rou's father thought she wasn't capable and wanted to marry her off as a second wife because her dowry wasn't much. However, her father passed away that year, and Xun Rou requested to observe three years of mourning. Later, when news came that the Prince of Huaiyin had annexed Qingzhou and Yanzhou, Xun Rou used this to prevent her stepmother from marrying her off easily, eventually choosing a promising young man, Ma Sichu, who was the military registrar of Linzhou at the time.

In fact, Xun Rou's life wasn't too bad. Huiyin had only made her taste the bitter fruit of her own design, but these rumors hadn't reached her hometown. She was being sent back to her family for marriage due to her age.

Since Li Cheng ascended the throne, Xun Rou had repeatedly requested to enter the palace to visit the Empress Dowager. However, since Huiyin was managing the palace affairs, she had the authority to decide who could visit and who couldn't.

The Empress Dowager was someone who was often confused, and Xun Rou was full of schemes. Putting these two together wouldn't lead to anything good.

"Ignore the request; there's no need to respond," said Huiyin.

The Empress Dowager was getting old, like Elder Madame Xu, not in power but with a high status. Knowing they were old, people couldn't do much about them.

Hearing Huiyin's response, Nanny Nan also breathed a sigh of relief. "It should be like this. Xun Rou isn't a good person; she has many tricks and schemes up her sleeve."

Huiyin smiled. "I'm not stupid. Why would I let her come? She's just the wife of a military registrar; what qualifications does she have to request an audience?" Oh, by the way, I saw that the prince's clothes were made very well yesterday. Please take four strings of cash to reward the clothes officer of the Imperial Clothes Bureau for their excellent work."

Nanny Nan left to carry out the order. This Clothes Officer Zhong was said to have a sister who recently bought a three-courtyard house and whose son had married with a generous dowry, raising suspicions within the Cui family.

Moreover, Clothes Officer Zhong had originally been under Empress He, which was already problematic. After being warned last time, the Imperial Clothes Bureau had been very diligent in their work.

However, Huiyin didn't directly deal with Clothes Officer Zhong. Instead, she publicly rewarded her to see how the person behind her would react.

If Clothes Officer Zhong wasn't a spy, and someone aware of the list knew it contained Clothes Officer Zhong, would they send an anonymous tip? If something happened to Clothes Officer Zhong or if she was reported and exposed, the spy might take Clothes Officer Zhong's position.

Upon receiving the reward from Huiyin, Clothes Officer Zhong was delighted, not because of the money itself, but because it represented the Empress's trust in her.

At her age, never having married and working hard to reach the position of Clothes Officer, it was hard to leave the palace where she was still respectfully called Lady Superintendent. Now trusted by the new Empress, Zhong used the reward money to buy wine and food for the Imperial Clothes Bureau staff.

"Today, the Empress rewarded me. While it’s credited to me, it couldn’t have happened without everyone’s help."

Having a meal with Clothes Officer Zhong were two Clothing Officers, two Garment Officers, and four Ladies, all from the Clothes Department. Currently, the Imperial Clothes Bureau had four departments, and Clothes Officer Zhong had temporarily managed the bureau, with the deepest seniority, making her a likely candidate for the next Lady Superintendent.

However, the decision rested with the Empress, so she personally oversaw the clothing production.

"It's all thanks to Clothes Officer Zhong's efforts; we just did some minor work."

Everyone laughed.

Another Garment Officer sitting nearby said, "I heard that the Head of the Ornament Department also intends to become the Lady Superintendent. The Empress was very pleased with a bath fragrance formula she presented the other day."

Clothes Officer Zhong glanced at Cai Zhangyi and thought to herself that she had been the one to recruit Cai Zhangyi, who was still quite junior in rank. However, it was always Cai Zhangyi who paid attention to details for her, acting as a sort of confidante. This was in contrast to the two lower-ranking officials beneath her, who were eyeing her position with envy.

Unbeknownst to her, Cai Zhangyi was a hidden spy planted by the Weis. Before Wei Liangdi entered the palace, the palace was recruiting female officials, and Cai Zhangyi had joined at that time. Yet, she remained just a Zhangyi and had not even been promoted to the rank of official. Clothes Officer Zhong was a very meticulous and hands-on person, managing the Bureau of Clothing tightly, which made it difficult for anyone to take action under her watch.

In recent days, there was news that the Empress had begun to suspect Clothes Officer Zhong. With a little push, if Zhong were to leave, the two incoming officials would not be as meticulous and would be more eager for quick success, making things easier to manage.

Children's skin is delicate. If they wear clothes soaked in poison, they would die without a clear cause, unlike in the kitchen where food is tested for toxins. Clothes are never tested in the same way.

Cai Zhangyi secretly stirred up trouble, hoping for a conflict to arise between Clothes Officer Zhong and another official.

After three days, Pei Shuo asked for an audience. Huiyin met her brother in a side hall and had her trusted aides guard the door.

"Brother, how did it go?" Huiyin asked.

Pei Shuo replied, "Your Majesty is exactly right. That woman from the Wei family appeared no different from other women on the surface, but she had warm quilts and carefully prepared food. I feared I might misjudge if she had used money, so I had someone search her room when she was unaware. No silver was found, and the fur came from places like Jinzhou. At night, an old woman delivering night soil often sneaked in to deliver food. I followed her for two days, only to find out she was disguised. She has been captured."

"Good. We should have a clearer picture soon. If we can find their base, there might be other uses for it," Huiyin said.

Pei Shuo then asked, "Should this matter be reported to His Majesty?"

Huiyin shook her head, "No need to trouble His Majesty yet. He is occupied with war and might get distracted."

The siblings chatted casually for a few more sentences before dismissing.

Huiyin then went to pay her respects to Empress Dowager. She specially brought some milk cakes and said, "Your Majesty, I tasted these milk cakes in the kitchen, and they were soft and flavorful. I offer them to the Ancestor."

At her age, Empress Dowager preferred easily digestible food. Seeing the box open to reveal the white and tender pastries, she couldn’t help but ask, "Are there any for the Crown Prince and the Second Prince? They enjoy these kinds of snacks."

"Rest assured, they each have some. Your Majesty, how has your health been lately? The weather is getting colder, and you must take good care of yourself," Huiyin said with a smile.

Empress Dowager nodded.

After some polite exchanges, Huiyin excused herself. After she left, Empress Dowager muttered, "The Zheng family often visits her, but few from our Xun family enter the palace, and when they do, they just follow the crowd."

Nanny Fan had long been Huiyin's ally. She thought to herself that since Xun Rou had done those things on her orders, Huiyin was now eyeing her again. And Marchioness Xun, who were both grandchildren of Empress Dowager, what feelings did they truly have for the Grand Empress Dowager?

But she couldn’t say that. Nanny Fan said, "Your Majesty, I heard that every time someone visits the Empress, rewards are given. Even the Empress privately complains that the storeroom items are insufficient. Since you are now a Marquise, if the Xun family comes to the palace asking for rewards or official positions, it would be difficult for you to grant their requests. Even if you do, it’s better to wait until the Emperor returns to have a say."

Empress Dowager's attention was oddly drawn to something else, "Are you saying the Empress is also short of money?"

Nanny Fan nodded, "Exactly. The Emperor is fighting wars outside and needs money. The internal treasury has been exhausted. Now, with many people in the palace needing their allowances and external meritorious officials requiring rewards, even Princess Wei living here needs help building a house. In winter, the entire palace makes winter clothes. To show the new court's benevolence, I heard the Empress said her relatives wouldn’t enter the palace for some time."

Empress Dowager's private treasury was quite abundant, so it was fine to reward her natal family, but if the Empress was short of money and she herself gave lavish rewards to her natal family, what if the Empress asked her for money? What would she do then?

With that thought, Empress Dowager decided to hold off.

**

Late at night, Huiyin looked at the list: Clothes Officer Zhong, Jiang Siyishi, Peng Neishi of the Gongde Hall, and the palace maid from the flower room in Linde Hall. The first four had suddenly become wealthy, while the last one's background was completely off.

"Fugui, the maid named Rou'er from the flower room is already twenty years old, right?" Huiyin asked.

Fugui confirmed, "Yes, she is twenty this year."

"How is her work?"

"She is quite meticulous, appears gentle and quiet, doesn’t talk much, and is liked by everyone."

"Tomorrow, find an opportunity to search her room. If you find any heavy gold or medicine packets, take her into custody immediately," Huiyin ordered.

She needed to act on the most obvious person on the list first, making them believe she trusted Cui Yuehua’s list. Naturally, the so-called evidence would be delivered to her, and everyone on the chain of connections would be implicated.

Fugui moved swiftly. She first had Rou'er deliver some flower pots to Elder Madame Xu, then searched her own quarters thoroughly but found nothing out of the ordinary. She had Lingjiu restore everything to its original state and erased the footprints, leaving her to stand guard.

When Rou'er returned after delivering the flowers, she was covered in mud and needed to change clothes. Lingjiu, hiding on the rafters, watched as she stripped off her outer garments and changed. Lingjiu waited until Rou'er left and inspected her again but found nothing.

Lingjiu reported back to Huiyin: "Your Majesty, there was nothing unusual. There was nothing on her."

"Was she wearing any jewelry on her head or body?" Huiyin narrowed her eyes.

Lingjiu thought for a moment. "Yes, a thin silver hairpin with amber at the tip."

"Take the hairpin apart and see if there's anything inside," Huiyin ordered.

Lingjiu nodded. Within a day, she returned to report: "Your Majesty, you were right. The hairpin contained a powder made from withered vines. The imperial doctors said that if placed on flowers, it could cause adults to vomit uncontrollably and might be fatal to children. No wonder we noticed you, who love flowers, haven’t been sending or receiving any recently."

Huiyin sighed. "It's impossible to guard against everything. I'm not omnipotent. Fortunately, this Rou'er wasn't too vicious. She can't be kept around. Her crimes should be made public, and the Palace Affairs Bureau should interrogate her. Ideally, she'll reveal her accomplices. If she doesn't confess, ensure she doesn’t die too soon. After her death, announce that she killed herself before we could extract a full confession."

Once the order was given, the Palace Affairs Bureau moved swiftly. Despite Rou'er's seemingly gentle name, she was tough and refused to talk. It wasn't until Huiyin gave a specific command that she broke, revealing that Xiao Neishi from the laundry bureau, who was often bullied, had been relaying messages for her.

Xiao Neishi and Rou'er were both executed on the spot for plotting against the imperial heirs and being spies for the Weis. Their heads were displayed for three days.

The incident shocked everyone. When Cui Yuehuan saw the heads hanging on the city wall, she flinched.

"This should serve as a deterrent."

Even Yin Lifang and Princess Wei, hearing of the event, visited Huiyin's palace. They comforted her but were also somewhat frightened. Yin Lifang wasn't surprised. Her sister had once mentioned how ruthless Princess Zheng could be toward her rivals. Now, facing someone who truly intended harm against the crown prince, she would be even less merciful.

As for Xun Rou, she had planned to use her improved circumstances to visit Elder Madame Xu and seek revenge. But seeing the heads on display made her faint, her heart pounding uncontrollably.

"Better to stay home quietly," she thought.

Elder Madame Xu also fell silent. Huiyin generally disliked violent people, but Li Heng and Huiyin were known to be ruthless. It was no wonder that in a previous life, Li Heng and Huiyin were a couple, and in this life, Li Cheng and Huiyin were as well.

...

Cai Dianyi, observing secretly, saw how the empress dealt with the palace maid who plotted against the crown prince. Emboldened, she began using her connections. She wrote an anonymous letter and, late at night, slipped it under the door of the Linde Palace. She also placed a packet of poison under Clothes Officer Zhong's bedding.

She believed that even if the empress investigated, she wouldn't trace it back to her. After all, she had nothing on her at the moment.

That night, she thought to herself that if this succeeded, the Weis would certainly reward her and her family. Her father, in his fifties and long disheartened in his career, would have a brighter future with the Weis' support.

Unexpectedly, the next morning, Zhong stood at her door. Zhong looked at her coldly. "I didn't expect you to be an eye of the Weis and try to frame me."

Cai Dianyi, not fully dressed, was confused. "Clothes Officer, what are you saying?"

Wasn't the empress supposed to come for her? After all, Rou'er was executed based solely on the poison.

Zhong said, "The Clothes Office has someone like you attempting to frame me. Your accomplice has already been caught. Empress Huiyin said your family has been detained by General Pei. The old woman, Qiao, you were in contact with, has also been captured. If you cooperate, the empress might allow you to see your father. If not, your fate will be the same as Rou'er’s."

Cai Dianyi, being of a higher rank than Rou'er, led to the discovery and elimination of ten hidden Weis agents.

...

Later, Madame Ji entered the palace and asked, "I didn't expect Clothes Officer Zhong to be innocent. How did you know there was a problem with Cai Dianyi?"

Huiyin smiled. "It was a case of mistaken identity. The emperor had warned me, but I already knew how to handle it. It’s absurd how Wei Duo has suffered such a loss!"

title: Chapter 85
content:
Chapter 85

◎Combined Chapter◎

In the morning, after organizing some palace affairs, Huiyin felt exhausted and in pain. She truly couldn't compare to some women who had exceptionally good health. The last time a lady visited the palace, she mentioned how her energy levels actually improved after giving birth. Even now, at over sixty years of age, she remained radiant and more vigorous than younger people.

However, Huiyin could not manage such feats. She definitely needed some rest. Around noon, feeling too lazy to have a proper meal, she had a few light snacks. It wasn't until after she woke up from her nap that she felt more comfortable.

The people serving her had also grown accustomed to this routine. Almost everyone would take a nap at noon. Nanny Nan brought over some needlework, Ling Lu prepared tea for everyone, and Huiyin read a book by the side.

After finishing the book, it suddenly occurred to her, "It seems my eldest brother has had another son."

Fugui smiled. "You have so much on your mind, my lady. Just yesterday, you sent me to the Pei family to check on things."

"I forgot because things have been so busy lately," Huiyin said.

Currently, her elder brother had two sons and a daughter. As for the boys, it was fine, but Huiyin had been thinking about arranging a marriage for Xianjie. She intended to marry Xianjie to Guo Zhao's eldest son, Guo Xing. This would be a union of old and new court officials.

Besides, Xianjie was sensible, and Guo Xing was a very prudent child. Their marriage might not be filled with passionate love, but it would be stable and good, which was better than many others.

However, it wasn't just about what she thought was good. She also had to consider whether her brother and sister-in-law agreed.

Marriage was about creating harmony between two families, not creating enmity.

It was also said that after giving birth to her son, Dong Shi needed more care due to postpartum bleeding, but her brows and eyes had relaxed. Although she had been married several times, she finally wed into the Pei family. Her husband was handsome, of high rank, and powerful, and she had even borne him a son. For her, life had reached a state of perfection.

Thus, she had someone donate five hundred taels to a temple as a charitable donation.

She wasn’t asking for anything else; she just wanted her future to be peaceful, which was more important than anything.

Pei Shuo understood Dong Shi's actions well. When he had needed financial and human resources the most, Dong Shi had helped him without hesitation, which was a great favor to him. All she needed was a place to stay, which he could easily provide.

This time, because Pei Shuo was the queen's brother and a General of the Flying Cavalry, a position much higher than the Jizhou Colonel, his home was bustling with activity. Seeing this, Xin Shi couldn't help but feel sour.

However, the relationship between a husband and wife largely depended on the power behind them. The Xin family, which had some reputation in Jizhou, was now insignificant in the newly established dynasty. So, although Xin Shi was sharp-tongued and had some difficult days, she eventually let it go.

Moreover, from her cold observation, Dong Shi was a gentle and obedient person. She even pushed Pei Shuo to visit Huiyin. Whether she was hiding malice or deliberately flattering, it was hard to say. But if she resorted to harsh measures against Dong Shi now, she might be seen as jealous. If Pei Shuo disliked her because of that, her life would become difficult.

This was why, despite her sour feelings, she still made sure the third-day ceremony for Dong Shi's son, Jian Ge, was grand, treating him as if he were her own son.

When Madame Ji saw this scene, she spoke to her son Pei Shuo about his wife. "Your wife is virtuous. You should treat her kindly."

"Don't worry, mother. I will never mistreat Xin Shi," Pei Shuo replied. Xin Shi was his first wife, the mother of his children. How could he mistreat her?

Madame Ji smiled. "That's good, that's good."

After finishing this topic, the mother and son moved on to discuss the completion of the Yuzhang Prince's Mansion. Pei Shuo's other task of staying in the capital was to monitor the Yuzhang Prince's Mansion.

Zheng Fang entered from outside and joined the conversation. "The Yuzhang Prince is finished. The group from the Wei King's territory, now leaderless, has split. Some have joined Wei Duo, and most have joined the emperor. The emperor is currently fighting Wei Duo on the frontlines. As the emperor of the Da Ye dynasty, many secretly side with him. But what does the Prince of Yuzhang have? He is merely a teenager, unskilled in archery and horsemanship, and barely literate. Even if he's a bit clever, can he really turn the world upside down? To play the part of a pig to catch the tiger, you still need to be a tiger."

"Father, I understand what you mean, but my sister has told me to pay close attention. I dare not neglect it." After witnessing his sister's handling of spies and how much weight her words carried, Pei Shuo's heart naturally leaned towards his sister.

Zheng Fang wasn't as open with his stepson as he was with Zheng Wuheng. He only sighed softly. "The emperor is not here right now, so it's natural that your sister is concerned. But if she becomes too concerned, the emperor might not like it."

He still held traditional male views. Pei Shuo wasn't without worry either, but after thinking about it, he smiled. "You don't know. The emperor hastily named the crown prince to secure my sister's position. Perhaps he needs her to be stronger to help protect the imperial throne for the crown prince."

Zheng Fang's mind immediately wandered. Yes, all his talk was based on the assumption that the emperor would return. But if the emperor didn't come back, with Huiyin's abilities and talent, she could indeed take charge. As the grandfather of the crown prince, he would certainly be heavily relied upon.

"Cough, cough, Father, what are you thinking about?" Pei Shuo poured wine for Zheng Fang.

Zheng Fang raised his cup and took a few small sips. "No, not really. Just that you have so much on your plate, it must be exhausting."

Pei Shuo smiled. "Why speak such words? Assigning tasks to me shows you trust me."

For Pei Shuo, this was actually a good thing. While fighting wars outside could lead to merits, with Yuwendang around, no one could surpass his achievements. Being able to help his sister in the capital and earn some favor with his nephew was more valuable than anything else. People feared being idle; a day or two of leisure was fine, but over time, one would fall behind.

Meanwhile, when it was mentioned that Yuzhang Prince's Mansion had been completed, Huiyin went to the Empress Dowager's palace and spoke to Princess Wei and Yin Lifang. "I plan to select an auspicious date for you to move in."

Princess Wei was delighted. "We must thank the Emperor and Empress for their care." Yin Lifang also added a few words.

Huiyin was pleased to see this, as she knew that while Princess Wei and Yin Lifang could maintain a temporary calm in the Empress Dowager's presence, it would be difficult once they left the palace.

Therefore, Huiyin wouldn't let them off so easily but pretended to be troubled. "However, I must first complain to both of you. With the new dynasty just starting and the Emperor away at war, the allowances might be limited. Please bear with us."

With the war outside, even the palace had to live frugally, let alone those outside the palace. Given the current situation, it was already good for the Yuzhang Prince to be accommodated.

Moreover, when under a low eave, one has to bow their head. This principle left Princess Wei and Yin Lifang without a rebuttal.

They would move to Yuzhang Prince's Mansion on a certain auspicious day after the Beginning of Spring.

Huiyin's maternal family, the Zheng family, along with the Pei family, Yuwendang's family, and the Guo family, specially came to congratulate them on their new home. Cui Yuehua, returning with Madame Ji, remarked, "Looking from the outside, Yuzhang Prince's Mansion seems quite grand, but inside it feels too delicate and not spacious enough."

Madame Ji smiled. "There aren’t many spacious places available for him. This mansion is beautifully built and suits him well. Compared to those sent to the imperial mausoleum, they are already in a good position."

Cui Yuehua nodded. "You're right."

Madame Ji smiled again. "With both the official mother and birth mother of the Yuzhang Prince living together, there could be trouble ahead."

"In the palace, they seem to be doing well," said Cui Yuehua.

"That’s because they’re under the Empress Dowager’s protection. The Empress Dowager isn’t someone who can quell troubles, but the Empress is different. If they keep causing trouble, they might never get out of the palace," said Madame Ji, feeling proud of her daughter.

Cui Yuehua remembered the list she had submitted last time, where only one person was problematic, and the rest were fine. She went to the palace to apologize, but instead of blaming her, the Empress praised her for her efforts.

This experience made Cui Yuehua more composed, realizing there were always others more capable. She understood that work couldn't be done hastily and had since become more convinced of Huiyin's capabilities.

As for Yin Lifang and the others moving in for the first time, it was up to them to decide the arrangements, not the palace. In fact, their statuses were now quite equal. Although Princess Wei was the official wife, she wasn't the birth mother of the Yuzhang Prince. This was the Yuzhang Prince's mansion.

Naturally, Princess Wei wanted to live in the best courtyard, and Yin Lifang was willing to do so too. However, she wasn't Yin Liyi, who could endure much, so in front of the Yuzhang Prince, she said, "Jing’er, let's give the best courtyard to Princess Wei."

"Mother..." The Yuzhang Prince was naturally closer to his birth mother, and Princess Wei's kindness was only because she didn't have a son of her own.

Yin Lifang gently shook her head and said to Princess Wei, "Princess, you should live in the upper courtyard."

Appearing deeply wronged, Jianjia couldn't help but defend her mother. "My mother is the official wife and should live in the upper courtyard."

Upon hearing this, Princess Wei immediately sensed trouble. Though inwardly pleased, Yin Lifang humbly agreed, "Yes, yes, we will follow the arrangements of the Princess and the Lady."

The young Yuzhang Prince didn't grasp the complexities and resented that despite his status, his mother had to yield. Princess Wei tried to mediate but to no avail. The Yuzhang Prince and Yin Lifang had already developed a deep resentment towards her.

However, Princess Wei had her own considerations. Her daughter wasn't married yet, and she needed this status. Otherwise, if Yin Lifang truly became the mistress, it would be awkward for her to appear in public. Therefore, she couldn't back down.

On the very first day, reports of the disputes in Yuzhang Prince's Mansion were sent to Huiyin, who smiled. "Let them fight with each other. It's better than them uniting against others, which wouldn't be a good thing."

Fugui said, "Yes, neither of them is good. Before, Princess Wei even tried to marry off her sister to our Emperor, ignoring proper decorum. As for Second Consort Yin, she’s always scheming. Despite her small stature, she’s quite cunning."

"Although the Yuzhang Prince is still a child, he is the lord of a mansion. How he handles disputes within the mansion will be a true test of his wisdom. If there’s disharmony in the Yuzhang Prince’s Mansion, it’ll be bad for them but great for us. Since the Princess Wei has taken the main courtyard, in the future, when we send gifts, we’ll give the same to both Yin Lifang and the Princess Wei, treating them as equals."

"Didn’t the Wei Imperial Consort, the Prince of Wei’s mother, constantly stir up trouble with the Grand Dowager Wu? Once she left the Prince of Wei’s Mansion, the Grand Dowager Wu didn’t dare to cause trouble anymore, which shows where the problem lies. Huiyin isn’t someone who forgets past wounds just because they’ve healed."

"When it comes to retaliation, she doesn’t hold back."

However, as she stood up and walked to the window, seeing the pink buds on the peach tree outside, she murmured, "You’ve been gone for half a year now… why haven’t you come back yet…?"

Li Cheng was battling fiercely on the front lines. He knew Wei Duo would be tough, but he didn’t expect him to be this difficult to handle. The reason he had been able to defeat Wei Duo before was purely because Wei Duo didn’t understand his tactics. Now, however, Wei Duo seemed to know his moves all too well, which was no surprise since some of Wei Duo’s subordinates had previously served under Li Cheng.

These men had fought alongside Li Cheng before, so they were familiar with his tactics and knew his personality well.

Li Cheng’s personality was very straightforward, unlike Huiyin’s. Huiyin could tolerate people she disliked and would wait for years to strike back with a well-thought-out plan. But Li Cheng was very particular. When he first saw the gift list Huiyin drafted, he found it inappropriate and revised everything. Fortunately, Huiyin didn’t mind at all.

Now, Wei Duo was deliberately targeting this trait of his, making him win unhappily and lose unwillingly.

Zheng Wuheng, being the youngest, didn’t dare to offer suggestions. Yuwendang, on the other hand, was eager to win this battle in one go, because if they retreated, Wei Duo would advance.

They had to endure the hardship and find another solution.

"Your Majesty, there is a letter from the Empress." A guard reported from outside.

When Li Cheng was toiling on the frontlines, his greatest comfort was reading the letters from Huiyin. However, Huiyin was very considerate and would only write once in a long while. Previously, there were spies from Wei Duo among his men, and it was only after great effort that they were rooted out. At that time, he couldn’t even send letters back for fear of interception.

Now that these people had been dealt with, he could finally send letters openly.

The letter began by saying that she didn’t intend to disturb him, but she missed him terribly since he had been away for so long. She also mentioned that she had caught many of Wei Duo’s spies in the capital.

Reading this, Li Cheng grinned. Huiyin was truly clever.

She also wrote that the peach buds had appeared by the window, but she didn’t know if the flowers would bloom by the time she could see him...

Li Cheng was also in pain, longing to return to his wife. The couple had been spending little time together for many years. Luckily, at the end of the letter, Huiyin reminded him that tough times call for patience and calm.

She had even tucked an old silk handkerchief into the letter—something Li Cheng knew she often used. At that moment, Li Cheng blushed.

His anxious heart was soothed considerably. The next day, he personally rewarded the army and discussed with Guo Zhao, Yuwendang, and Zheng Wuheng in the tent. It was clear to all of them that Li Cheng seemed much more spirited.

"They either ambush our granary or try to bribe our people. There are a few useful men when fighting, but that’s because they know my tactics. This time, I need to devise a strategy that he cannot predict, with people he cannot foresee." After saying this, Li Cheng looked at Zheng Wuheng.

Although Zheng Wuheng had some experience, he was still like a new recruit among them. Seeing everyone’s eyes on him, he hurriedly replied, "Your Majesty, I don’t have any other ideas right now."

Li Cheng smiled and said, "Just speak your mind. Even if you’re wrong, I won’t blame you."

Encouraged by his brother-in-law, Zheng Wuheng spoke up, "I believe that old traitor Wei Duo loves land battles and prefers cunning tactics. If we don’t react to his moves and remain unmoved, what can he do to us?"

"What you said makes sense. But if we stay still, he’ll attack. We can’t retreat; instead, we need to raise the stakes." Li Cheng also came up with a good plan.

Both sides wanted to lure the enemy in, but it wasn’t going to be easy.

Wei Duo was currently trying to recruit Zhao Hong, but Zhao Hong wanted to surrender to Li Cheng. Li Cheng had initially planned to accept him but then thought of a better strategy.

However, Yuwendang said, "Won’t this be easy to turn a ruse into reality?"

"This is exactly a test. If Zhao Hong and Wei Duo join forces, we’ll let them win two battles and allow them to come from Pingshan. Then, we’ll flank them from behind." Li Cheng quickly devised a strategy.

It was a risky move, but they had no other choice.

After formulating the strategy, Li Cheng led his soldiers in daily training, working very hard. The grain supplies from several regions arrived in a timely manner. Zheng Wuheng trained alongside his brother-in-law without complaint. In this regard, the two brothers, Zheng Wuheng and Pei Shuo, were alike. Unlike Zheng Fang, who was indecisive and often changed his mind, the brothers were loyal and steadfast."

With the frontline so tense, the palace regained its calm after Princess Wei and Yin Lifang left.

However, Huiyin still couldn't fully relax, knowing that some of Wei Duo's spies remained undetected. What disappointed her most was that Yuwendang's daughter was to marry Guo Zhao's son. The two fathers had arranged the marriage on the battlefield.

Since Guo Xing was now engaged, he could no longer stay in the palace. Huiyin prepared many gifts for him to take back to his mansion. Jiang Bipbo had already prepared the mansion, eagerly awaiting Guo Xing's return. Every arrangement and decoration was personally overseen by her to ensure her stepson would be content.

When she married, Guo Xing was only seven and had been raised in the Huaiyin Mansion by the Empress. Now, five or six years had passed, and the child had grown into a young man. He even had a marriage proposal and would wed in two or three years. He had been granted the title of heir, so he could no longer be treated as an ordinary child.

Before returning to the mansion, Guo Xing had confided in the Crown Prince about getting along with his stepmother.

The Crown Prince, sounding like a small adult, reassured him, "What are you afraid of? I've heard my mother mention her. She's very capable and can manage several businesses on her own. Even if she were to make things difficult, I'm still here. And my mother will stand up for you. Don't be afraid."

Bringing her thoughts back, Jiang Bipbo was already quite excited but managed to hold herself back. "Good child, I've prepared a courtyard for you. If there's anything you don't like, just say so. Come, Shi Jie, come and greet your brother."

Guo Shi, Guo Zhao's beloved daughter, was cherished like a precious gem. Despite her young age, she was sensible and well-mannered. She quickly came forward to greet her brother.

Guo Xing breathed a sigh of relief.

Unknown to him, Xin Shi was quite pleased with the marriage between the Guo and Yuwendang families. Although the Empress had previously hinted at it, Xin Shi believed her daughter could also be a Crown Princess. However, this was just a thought in her heart.

After a few cups of wine, she revealed some of her intentions to Pei Shuo. "I really didn't expect the Yuwendang and Guo families to form a marriage alliance so quickly. I also thought highly of Guo Xing when we were in Xuzhou."

Pei Shuo took a sip of wine. "The Guo family is newly ennobled, and Guo Xing, as the heir and the Crown Prince's study companion, has a promising future. What a pity."

"Actually, there's no need to feel sorry. Our daughter's good days might still be ahead," Xin Shi said with a smile.

Pei Shuo was puzzled. "What do you mean? Are you eyeing a young man with a higher official rank and better prospects for our Xianjie?"

Xin Shi smiled but said nothing.

Pei Shuo thought for a moment. "The son of Yuwendang doesn't seem to be like his father. The grandson of Prime Minister Jian could be a match, and the Xun family wants to marry into our family, but they seem like mediocre and clingy people."

"You can aim a bit higher," Xin Shi suggested.

She thought her husband would guess, but instead, Pei Shuo said, "The Prince of Yuzhang? No, no, while the Prince of Yuzhang is a commandery prince, his family is complicated. These royal families will not have real power in the future. If our daughter were to marry into such a family, the rules would be strict, and it wouldn't be practical."

Xin Shi shook her head and wrote two characters on the table with wine. Pei Shuo quickly wiped it off, feeling his heart race. "Are you crazy? The Empress has no such intention."

"What if I'm just daydreaming? Our Xianjie is not lacking in any way. She's also the niece of the Empress, who adores her. The Empress loves our Xianjie so much." Xin Shi didn't think it was impossible.

Pei Shuo, however, said, "You're being blinded by all this splendor. If the frontline battle is victorious and His Majesty returns triumphant, the entire Da Ye dynasty will undergo a major reshuffle. If our daughter were to become the Crown Princess, how could the old ministers who followed the Emperor be content? Do you think it's a coincidence that the Guo family suddenly formed a marriage alliance with Yuwendang's family now? It's clear the Guo family wants to nip the possibility of Yuwendang's daughter becoming the Crown Princess in the bud."

Hearing this, Xin Shi understood. "Are you saying the Guo family intends to marry their daughter to the Crown Prince?"

Pei Shuo nodded. "I'm afraid that's exactly their plan. Lady Guo is the sworn sister of the Empress, and Guo Zhao, a man from a humble background, has risen to become a count. They are making careful plans step by step! So I say you're being blinded."

Chapter 86

◎Combined Chapter◎

As evening approached and the rosy clouds faded, darkness settled in. Huiyin had always disliked the deepening twilight. She always felt that everything became frightening at night, and her sensitivity would peak. In the past, she rarely thought of Li Cheng, but now she found herself thinking of him more often.

At least when he was by her side, he was like a guardian, keeping her free from any tension.

To outsiders, she seemed invincible and strategically flawless, but beneath that tough exterior, she was someone who feared the night. She didn’t dare reveal this weakness, afraid of being controlled by those around her.

That night, she tossed and turned, unable to sleep, and the next morning, she couldn’t get up, so she stayed in bed a little longer.

When she rose, she applied a lot of powder under her eyes. It was her birthday, and with the ongoing war at the frontlines, she didn’t want to hold a grand celebration. She only invited the descendants of meritorious officials to the palace to strengthen ties, hosted a few banquets, and bestowed gifts as a gesture of favor.

“Your Highness, didn’t you sleep well last night?” asked Lingju.

Huiyin smiled. “Before bed, I read a fascinating book that kept me awake, thinking about the story. Do I look worn out?”

“Your face used to be as smooth as a peeled egg, like white jade, but now you have dark circles under your eyes,” Lingju replied truthfully, knowing Huiyin preferred honesty.

Huiyin nodded. “I thought so too, but there’s no help for it. I’ve always been a light sleeper.”

Alone in the vast palace, she had to protect her son and maintain control, all while keeping her vulnerabilities hidden.

After dressing properly and looking at her dignified appearance, Huiyin rose, satisfied, though she felt a bit shaky from staying up too late. She could barely hold herself up.

In fact, the noblewomen faced even greater challenges. They had to rise before dawn, dress in grand attire, avoid eating foods with strong smells, and wait in their carriages for the palace gates to open. Once the gates opened, they entered in an orderly manner, holding their breath and not speaking casually. Once they reached Linde Hall, they had to kneel and bow in greeting. It was indeed not easy.

The older women had to be helped up, and even the younger ones, burdened with heavy attire, had to bow again to wish her a happy birthday. Even Madame Ji had to kneel.

Seated above, Huiyin said to everyone, “Today is my birthday, and it’s truly an honor for you all to come.”

“Your Highness, it’s our honor to enter the palace and celebrate your birthday. It’s a privilege for us,” said Cui Yuehuan, the wife of the Empress’s brother and the princess of the ducal palace, who was the first to speak, which was most appropriate.

Huiyin smiled slightly, and the palace maidens brought tea. She then said, “This is a new tea. I found it a bit bitter at first, but then it had a sweet aftertaste. It’s different from the fresh, tender early spring tea we had before.”

Jiang Bibo, whose family used to be in the tea business, chimed in, “Your Highness’s tea is excellent. I didn’t find it bitter. Instead, it had a very fragrant smell, not the grassy scent of tea but a kind of roasted and aromatic flavor.”

“You certainly know your tea. This one was roasted, making it particularly fragrant and flavorful,” Huiyin said, sipping lightly. She actually didn’t dare to drink much, afraid it would keep her awake.

Jiang Bibo quickly said she didn’t dare to claim such expertise.

Huiyin then asked about Madame Yu and Jiang Bibo, “Have your families completed the formal engagement process yet?”

Madame Yu rarely took her daughter out, so Huiyin had only seen the child when she was very young. Now, both families were important ministers, so she felt she had to ask.

Jiang Bibo smiled. “We’ve just matched the eight characters, and everything is good.”

“That’s wonderful. When they marry, I’ll make sure to give them a generous gift,” Huiyin said with a smile.

As for Madame Ji, since she often entered the palace, it wasn’t appropriate to say too much in front of others, so she just asked, “How are the Crown Prince and the Second Prince?”

Huiyin replied, “Today is my birthday, and they are resting for half a day. They will come to pay their respects in the afternoon.”

Jing’er, though young, had many people who wanted to climb the social ladder through him. She couldn’t let Jing’er casually meet people. Young children rarely had the ability to distinguish good from bad. No matter how mature they appeared, they could easily fall into the trap of thinking that indulgence equals love and strictness means cruelty. Not to mention outsiders, even those around him, if any wet nurse was too overbearing, Huiyin would send them away.

So, she deliberately kept these people at a distance.

When Li Cheng returned and her son could take part in governing, at least he wouldn’t be led astray.

Having said that, she waved to Xianjie, "Come sit beside me."

She didn’t have a daughter of her own; Xianjie was her brother's child. Although she wouldn’t dare say she treated Xianjie as her own, she hoped this child would be happier than both her and De Yin in the future. They were both products of political marriages, and their happiness largely depended on their husbands. Xianjie's situation was much better than theirs had been at her age.

Seeing how Princess Huiyin favored Xianjie, Jiang Bipbo lamented that her husband had already arranged an engagement with Yuwendang's daughter. Xianjie, being the niece of the Empress, was young but strikingly beautiful, far prettier than Yuwendang Chonghua. Yuwendang was handsome and talented, and his wife, Yuwendang's mother, was petite and charming, but their daughter, Chonghua, had sallow skin and was somewhat overweight.

Of course, marriage was about uniting two families, and Jiang Bipbo would never express such thoughts outwardly. However, men with beautiful wives often sought affairs elsewhere, let alone when the wife was just average-looking.

It wasn’t that Jiang Bipbo looked down on them; she simply observed that her stepson was quite arrogant and had been brought up in the Empress's court, giving him refined tastes. Given his tastes, he should marry someone who was both talented and beautiful, but this engagement seemed rather hasty.

But Jiang Bipbo knew her place well enough not to say anything she shouldn’t. After all, she was just a stepmother, and her role was to execute, not to question.

Xin Shi, seeing the Empress dote on her daughter, was pleased but added, "If Madame Huiyin loves her, she also thinks of Madame. This is a pair of pouches she made at home to celebrate your birthday."

A palace maid quickly brought them over. Upon seeing the soft green satin pouches embroidered with pink peaches, Huiyin commented, "Xianjie can already make pouches—that's really impressive!"

Xianjie, a bit shy, said, "I am unworthy of your praise, Madame."

"Nanny Nan, I remember we have a few gilded fans. Bring them over for Xianjie to play with," Huiyin said lovingly.

Watching this, Cui Yuehua wished she had a daughter of her own. She had no objections to Xianjie; after all, she was the only girl in their family, and everyone adored her.

Then Huiyin asked the other family members how they were doing in the capital and whether they were adapting well. She also bestowed rare and valuable gifts such as precious prayer beads, tribute silks, and rare incense that could not be obtained outside. She even had the Shengping Bureau prepare two short plays for entertainment. After the performance, they had a meal before she dismissed them.

While the other noble ladies left, Ji Shi, Xin Shi, and Cui Yuehua stayed behind for further conversation.

During such moments, Ji Shi and Cui Yuehua often engaged in subtle competition, sharing what they knew from the streets. Cui Yuehua, feeling she hadn’t performed well last time, had gathered a lot of information this time: "I heard that the Yuwendang girl is quite obese and sallow, so the Yuwendang family rarely lets her appear in public. This engagement with the Guo family aims to leverage the friendship between the two families' elders to secure the marriage before any social interactions expose the truth."

This was the downside of blind marriages, where families only considered status or relied on mutual connections, without regard for whether the couple was truly compatible.

"As they say, beauty is in the eye of the beholder. As long as the girl's personality is good, that's enough," Huiyin said.

Hearing Cui Yuehua's account of Yuwendang Chonghua, Huiyin thought of something else: "I heard that Princess Jianjia of the Yuzhang Kingdom is also looking for a son-in-law. They have only recently arrived in the capital and don’t know many people. I believe they plan to host a flower banquet. In my opinion, they are trying to find a good match through the banquet."

This was only natural. Huiyin understood that the Princess Wei and her household certainly had money, but it wasn’t an unlimited amount. It was likely reserved for Jianjia's dowry.

However, whom Jianjia chose to marry was not her concern.

King Wei was dead, and many of his former subordinates had sided with Wei Duo. The rest had either joined Li Cheng or dispersed like birds and beasts. Unless the Yuzhang King was exceptionally talented, he wouldn’t make much of an impact.

"If she wants to look for a match, let her. I believe the Yuzhang King is also of marriageable age, so their mansion will soon be bustling with activity."

These matters were of little importance to her, and she discreetly stifled a yawn. Seeing this, Ji Shi asked, "Is Madame tired?"

"I caught a cold yesterday and didn’t sleep well last night," Huiyin waved her hand.

Upon seeing this, Ji Shi and the others knew not to linger and left. Since Huiyin did not ask Xianjie to stay, Xin Shi took her daughter home, feeling a bit regretful.

Once they left, Huiyin returned to her bedroom, removed her hair ornaments, washed her face, and hurried to bed.

Fugui tucked Huiyin into bed, then she and Nanny Nan did some needlework nearby. Fugui said, "Madame is truly hardworking; there isn’t a single day when she can relax."

"Indeed," Nanny Nan agreed with concern. "Last year, when Madame had her monthly troubles, there were many spies and traitors. She still had to go out at night to check on the Crown Prince and the Second Prince, which led to discomfort below. Being alone, she has to be both father and mother to them, which is truly not easy. Outsiders know nothing; they only see her as being deeply favored, but they only see the glamorous side. Who knows the inner struggles?"

Princess Wei was deeply concerned about her daughter Jianjia's marriage, especially since younger girls like Guo Xing were getting engaged, while Jianjia still had no husband.

Jianjia had grown up, and Princess Wei discussed the matter with her. "Don't be shy; this is your lifelong affair. This time, it's up to us, not like in the past when your father was in charge."

Mentioning Prince Wei, Jianjia said, "If Father were still alive, why would we need to live under someone else's roof and put up with others' attitudes?"

"Even if your father were alive, he might not have done any better than your cousin. We would still have had to endure that Xu witch. Let's not talk about her; her death was quite gruesome. I never liked Xu Cifei. The two of them colluded with Wei Duo, leading to the downfall of Wei territory. Otherwise, how could we have ended up like this?" Princess Wei disliked Xu Cifei, and this shared resentment was mutual.

Jianjia also recalled the past. Her mother was always drinking those medicinal concoctions, hoping to have another son. They had to curry favor with Yin Cifei and treat Li Jing well, all to ensure future support.

Alas, everything had come to nothing. Life had changed drastically in just a few short years, as if in a dream.

Princess Wei didn't know many people, so she sent invitations to those she did know, preparing food and wine. Although Yin Lifang was temporarily living under someone else's roof, she refused to be seen as inferior.

Qiaozhen advised, "If you don't go out, people will think you're inferior. Why not sit with her on equal footing? Even in the palace, the Empress bestows gifts equally to both of you."

"Yes, I am the birth mother of the Prince of Yu Zhang. If I claim to be ill, it would only show weakness. In the palace, I've seen how Princess Zheng is full of vigor, and no one dares to underestimate her. Who would dare to deceive her?" Yin Lifang had been cautious due to her status, but now, because of the same status, why should she cower? Without her son, there would be no mansion, and where would that Huo family show off their power?

Not to mention the flower banquet where Princess Wei and Yin Cifei were at odds. As for Jianjia among the new elite, she wasn't as sought-after as the younger Xianjie. Those in the know were clear that when the Emperor established his own household, there had been some dissatisfaction from Prince Wei's side, so these people were holding back.

However, there were some large families in the capital who didn't know these details, and two of them had sent matchmakers to propose marriage.

This was far from what Princess Wei had imagined. Instead of a flood of proposals, there were merely two, and she wasn't very satisfied with either. Yin Lifang also sighed, "Sister, Jianjia's age can't be delayed any longer. Even if we settle on a marriage this year, preparations will take two years."

The adults' matters were kept from the children. Even though Yin Lifang showed her grievances in front of her son, she never directly spoke ill of Princess Wei.

"Yes, marriage preparations take several years," Princess Wei calculated, counting on her fingers.

Soon after, Princess Wei also enlisted the help of Madame Sun, who was the wife of an old minister from Wei territory and had a good relationship with Princess Wei. When Princess Wei asked for her assistance, Madame Sun thought of someone. "If we're talking about family background, there is indeed someone. I heard that the Emperor's cousin, Cui Erlang, recently lost his wife. The Cui family is a prominent clan, and he is a handsome and distinguished man."

Princess Wei directly went to the palace to request Huiyin's help for this match, knowing that it couldn't be done privately, or it would raise suspicions of collusion.

Sure enough, Huiyin smiled and said, "Cui Erlang lost his wife, but how could he match a princess? I believe we should find someone of appropriate age and appearance."

"Does the Empress have a candidate? We are like headless flies, widows without occupation, knowing nothing," Princess Wei hoped Huiyin could arrange an excellent match.

Huiyin smiled faintly, "I've been in the palace for so long; I don't know many people."

Although Princess Wei was somewhat disappointed, she didn't lose heart after leaving the palace and actually found a match. It wasn't someone else, but the son of Xun Rou's stepmother. Both sides were relatives and hit it off immediately.

Princess Wei and Jianjia were very happy. The two of them sat together by the candlelight, eating hot pot with great enthusiasm, looking forward to the day Jianjia would marry. The Xun family was royalty, and as long as the Emperor was there, their daughter would be safe. The young man was good at painting, had a proper appearance, and was a good match.

Such a warm scene was something Yin Liyi couldn't enjoy. She also had a son and a daughter, but Madame Xie's attitude towards her had changed drastically, cursing her as a reincarnated disaster star. Xie Jiuyi, who should have been on her side, was unusually silent, leaving Yin Liyi to suffer in silence these days.

Today, Xie Jiuyi had gone out, and her two children were eating with her. Her daughter was fine, but her son hadn't even finished his meal before shouting that he wanted to go to his grandmother's.

"Son, you haven't finished your meal yet? Grandmother is old and can't tolerate much noise. It's better to stay here with me," Yin Liyi said.

For nearly two years, she had been with her children, rarely leaving the estate. Xie Jiuyi seldom allowed them to leave, so she knew nothing of the outside world, let alone her sister and nephews.

But she avoided bringing it up again. This was a knot in her and Xie Jiuyi's hearts. Mentioning it would only lead to mutual pain and suffering.

When Xie Jiuyi returned today, he wasn't in his usual bitter state. He even volunteered, "I found out where your sister is."

"Really? Where?" Yin Liyi immediately sat up in bed.

Xie Jiuyi rarely smiled, "Your nephew has been enfeoffed in the capital, and it's likely your sister is living there too."

Yin Liyi was delighted. She didn't want to speculate, but what if her sister hadn't been living well? Would Xie Jiuyi still be indifferent towards her?

You can't dwell too much on these things. Back then, when he married me, it looked like he was just marrying the daughter of a minor official, but could it also have been because of my sister?

**

In the blink of an eye, it was the end of another year. Huiyin was organizing the palace staff to clean the palace. Recently, some of the palace maids had been dismissed, and a new batch of young maids had been recruited from Jizhou, Qingzhou, and Xizhou.

A new group of people had taken their place. Huiyin looked at her copper mirror and seemed to have aged another year.

She used to hate those women who complained about being trapped in their homes, but now she was starting to show some of those tendencies. It was truly a regret to urge her husband to seek honors. But thankfully, the tough battle against Wei Duo was finally over, and she would soon be able to see her husband.

They hadn’t seen each other in two years. She wondered if he had become rough? Also, could he have fallen in love with someone else on the frontlines? If he fell in love with someone else, should she do the same?

However, she didn’t seem to have much interest in men.

Lost in her thoughts, she glanced up and saw another person in the mirror. Startled, Huiyin stood up, “You, how did you suddenly appear behind me? Is this a hallucination?”

Li Cheng had been longing for Huiyin all the way, so he decided to return early with his men, wanting to surprise her. He didn’t ask anyone to announce him but was pinched by his wife as soon as he arrived. He deliberately grimaced, completely disregarding his image, just happy, and hugged his wife tightly.

“It’s not a hallucination, it’s really me who has returned. I didn’t stop riding to see you sooner,” Li Cheng felt her warmth and heartbeat and didn’t want to let go.

Originally, Huiyin wanted to say something sentimental, but seeing his well-shaved face and neatly combed hair, she smiled, “You didn’t ride straight through. You must’ve stopped to clean up along the way.”

Li Cheng’s ears turned slightly red, “That’s because you said I smelled like a horse after riding, and wouldn’t let me touch you.”

“I was just looking out for my own health. You don’t know how often I couldn’t sleep when you weren’t by my side. Really...” Huiyin coquettishly told him.

Li Cheng simply scooped her up in his arms and carried her to the bed.

Two hours later, they emerged. Li Cheng felt like all his bones and muscles had been cleared. Huiyin muttered, “I thought you would bring a younger sister back for me?”

“In all honesty, was what I just did not enough? I’ve been holding back for two years. At this intensity, are you trying to wrong me?” Li Cheng felt wronged.

Just now, Huiyin had complained that he had become darker and even suggested he had an affair outside, which was completely wronging him.

From riding and fighting in wars, calluses had formed on his legs.

Huiyin smiled and waved her hands, “Alright, alright, alright. Our conversation is too embarrassing to be heard. Tell me, how did you win? You have no idea how worried I was. Wei Duo, that old villain, had endless tricks up his sleeve.”

In her previous life, when she was the Empress Dowager, her father was initially unafraid of fighting Wei Duo but later became somewhat fearful.

Li Cheng smiled as he walked, “Thanks to my older cousin. He sent word that there was a major spy close to me. So, I couldn’t write letters and specially sent plums to you. You did your part well.”

“Oh, it was him,” Huiyin suddenly understood why Li Cheng didn’t write letters but sent plums instead.

Li Cheng smiled, “Yeah, I also deliberately designed for Zhao Hong to actively surrender to Wei Duo. To gain trust, I relied on this cousin. If I had initially conferred a title to the Cui family, they might not have fought so hard. This cousin might not have been helping me, but seeing my growing momentum, he switched sides. In the end, Wei Duo was killed by me, and Zhao Hong has surrendered to the court.”

Most of the territory of the Da Ye dynasty had been captured. Huiyin also sighed, “These things were hard for us to imagine before, but now they have been achieved.”

Li Cheng added, “I also want to thank your breastplate. I originally thought it was a bit cumbersome. Who wears two breastplates? But on that day, Wei Duo faked his death, and his heart was on the right side. He wanted to shoot me off my horse, but because of the breastplate, it saved my life.”
